title: How to Eat Cabbage

steps.headline: Steam cabbage for a quick, healthy side dish.
steps.description: Shred a cabbage and rinse it all, then put it straight into a skillet without drying off the water, which will make the cabbage steam. Heat the skillet covered over medium-high heat until it starts to steam, then lower the heat to medium and steam the cabbage for about 5 minutes. Uncover the skillet and stir in any seasonings you want to like salt, pepper, and butter, then cook the cabbage for 2 more minutes.You could serve this side dish with anything you want, such as a roasted chicken or roast beef.

steps.headline: Fry or saute cabbage to keep it crispy.
steps.description: Cut up a head of cabbage into strips and stir-fry the cabbage with other vegetables and proteins to turn it into a hearty main course. Saute it on its own with olive oil, salt, and pepper to make a simple side dish for any meal.For example, you could stir fry cabbage with chicken, carrots, broccoli, and any other vegetables you want in soy sauce, ginger, and garlic to make a Chinese-style stir-fried cabbage dish.

steps.headline: Grill cabbage to give it a smokey flavor.
steps.description: Cut a head of cabbage into 4 wedges and spread each cut side with butter or brush it with olive oil. Season it to taste with salt and pepper, then cook it on a hot grill for about 5 minutes per side or until it is tender.You can serve grilled cabbage with toppings like crispy crumbled bacon and blue cheese or ranch dressing.

steps.headline: Braise cabbage to make it tender and savory.
steps.description: Cut 1/2 a head of cabbage and 1/2 an onion into ⁄4 in (0.64 cm) slices and cook them in melted butter in a skillet over medium-high heat for 5 minutes or until they are translucent. Pour in 1  c (240 mL) of water, 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of white or apple cider vinegar, 1 tbsp (12.6 g) of sugar, and 1 tsp (6 g) of salt, 2 tsp (4.5 g) of caraway seeds. Stir everything together, reduce the heat to low, and cook the cabbage for 20-25 minutes.Serve braised cabbage with a fresh pat of butter on top for extra flavor.

steps.headline: Remove the outer leaves and wash a head of cabbage before using it raw.
steps.description: Peel off the softer, looser outer leaves of the head of cabbage. Rinse the whole head thoroughly under cool running water to get rid of any dirt or residues on the outside of the cabbage.The inner leaves of a head of cabbage are stuck together very tightly, which keeps out most dirt, so you don’t need to wash each layer of leaves. Removing the looser outer leaves gets rid of the dirtiest layer and lets you rinse away any dirt that might have gotten underneath them.

steps.headline: Shred cabbage and make it into a coleslaw for a summery side.
steps.description: Slice a head of cabbage into 4 quarters, then slice each quarter horizontally into thin leaves. Shred 2-3 carrots with a grater and mix the pieces together with the shredded cabbage along with a coleslaw dressing of your choice.Tip: Use both green and red cabbage to brighten up your coleslaw. For example, you could make a creamy buttermilk coleslaw to serve along with BBQ’d ribs or brisket for a traditional side dish.

steps.headline: Add cabbage to salads for extra color, texture, and nutrition.
steps.description: Shred, tear, or chop cabbage leaves and toss them with your other favorite vegetables, fruits, and salad dressings. Cabbage adds a nice crunchy texture and lots of healthy vitamins.Cabbage goes nicely with the sweetness of apples or oranges in summery salads.

steps.headline: Put shredded cabbage on top of tacos for a Mexican-American-style taco night.
steps.description: Use raw shredded cabbage along with diced onions and tomatoes or pico de gallo to top hard-shelled ground beef tacos. Add other toppings like grated cheddar cheese and hot sauce to finish it off.You could also try making a Southern California-style cabbage coleslaw with lime and cilantro to top something like fish tacos.

steps.headline: Toss some cabbage in your soup to add nutrients.
steps.description:
Tear or shred 1/2 a head of cabbage up and toss the leaves into any kind of soup that you’re cooking. Try adding cabbage to soups like minestrone, bean soup, ramen, or hot and sour soup for example.Tip: Red and green cabbage have the same flavor, so you can interchange them in dishes. Keep in mind that red cabbage will change the color of the dishes you cook it in. However, red cabbage also has higher concentrations of vitamins like Vitamin C.
You could also make a soup based entirely around cabbage, such as a creamy bacon and cabbage soup or a German-style cabbage soup.

steps.headline: Wrap cabbage leaves around ground meat to make stuffed cabbage rolls.
steps.description: Blanch whole cabbage leaves in boiling water for about 1 minute and wrap the leaves around seasoned ground pork, beef, or lamb. Put the rolls in a baking dish and bake them at 350 °F (177 °C) for 1-1 1/2 hours or until the filling is cooked.For Mediterranean- or Middle Eastern-style stuffed cabbage rolls, season ground lamb with allspice, cinnamon, garlic, and lemon. You can also mix cooked rice in. To make Polish- or Hungarian-style stuffed cabbage rolls, use ground pork and serve the rolls with a tomato sauce or with sour cream and paprika. Use about 1 lb (0.45 kg) of ground meat for every 8 cabbage leaves you want to stuff.

steps.headline: Make corned beef and cabbage for a traditional Irish meal.
steps.description: Cover a corned beef roast with water in a pot or dutch oven and simmer it over medium heat for about 50 minutes per 1 lb (0.45 kg) of meat. Put 10 small red potatoes, 5 sliced carrots, and 1 head of cabbage cut into wedges into the pot around the corned beef and keep simmering until the vegetables are tender. Remove the meat, slice it, and eat it alongside the cabbage and vegetables with some of the broth drizzled on top.This is a great recipe idea for a St. Patrick’s day party. Drink a pint of Guinness with your corned beef and cabbage for extra points. You can turn the leftovers from this recipe into a corned beef hash for breakfast the following day. Just chop everything up and fry it in a pan with some oil, then top it with a fried egg and enjoy.

steps.headline: Cook cabbage with pork or bacon for a savory main dish.
steps.description: Cabbage goes well with all kinds of pork dishes. Stew a cabbage head cut into wedges along with 1 lb (0.45 kg) of pork shoulder or pork belly cut into chunks in a slow cooker for 6-8 hours, for example.Sauteed cabbage also makes a good side or topping for all kinds of pork sausages or even mixed and fried together with sliced sausages or bacon.

steps.headline: Make cabbage into spicy kimchi for a Korean fermented condiment.
steps.description: Mix cut cabbage with scallions, radish, and a paste made out of hot red peppers, garlic, ginger, and fish sauce or salted shrimp. Pack the kimchi into a jar and press it down until the vegetables are all submerged. Let it ferment for at least 5 days.Kimchi is delicious in soups or as a topping for rice and meat dishes. Traditional kimchi is fermented underground for months at a time, but you can make this quick version at home.
